alert.note: Alert for Brown; Calumet; Door; Florence; Forest; Kewaunee; Langlade; Lincoln; Manitowoc; Marathon; Menominee; Northern Marinette County; Northern Oconto County; Oneida; Outagamie; Portage; Shawano; Southern Marinette County; Southern Oconto County; Vilas; Waupaca; Waushara; Winnebago; Wood (Wisconsin) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS GreenBay (East Central Wisconsin - Green Bay)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued December 23 at 6:19AM CST by NWS GreenBay
info.description: ...BLOWING AND DRIFTING SNOW WILL CREATE HAZARDOUS TRAVEL CONDITIONS TODAY... An large low pressure system centered near Toronto will continue to intensify this morning. Northwest winds on the western flank of the storm will continue to increase this morning, and should reach 25 to 35 mph across the entire area by late morning. Gusts to around 45 mph are possible. The strong winds will produce widespread blowing and drifting snow, resulting in hazardous travel conditions across the area. Travel in open areas will be especially difficult as the visibility could be reduced to near zero at times. Use extra caution if traveling today. If possible, consider postponing any long travel across open areas until conditions improve. In addition to the blowing and drifting snow, the wind will combine with cold air across the area to drive wind chill indices over all but Door County into the 25 below to 40 below zero range this morning. Wind chills this low indicate exposed skin can suffer frostbite in as little as 10 to 20 minutes. Be sure to wear appropriate winter clothing if going outdoors. Disturbances wrapping back around the western flank of the storm system will bring periods of light snow to northern and eastern Wisconsin, and occasional light snow and flurries to central portions of the state. One of the stronger disturbances will drop across east-central Wisconsin during the afternoon hours, possibly producing an inch or two of snow. Flow across Lake Superior will result in heavy snow showers at times in the snowbelt. Travel in this area will be especially difficult.
